p: In terms of activity, large differences were found, depending on the authors cited. Eugenol and thymol serve as good examples. Both compounds exhibited excellent activity in some studies (from 12.5 mg/L for eugenol [ 58] and 1.56 mg/L for thymol [ 26]), and in other studies, the activity was very poor (up to 80,000 for both [ 59]). These differences may be related, for example, to a different purity of the compound, a different fungal suspension density, or even to the use of other Candida strains with different sensitivities to chemical substances. A number of other factors, such as the type of culture medium, pH of the medium, incubation time, and temperature may likewise influence the antimicrobial activity [ 20].
